cooking_method: Boil tomatillos, onion, jalapenos, and garlic until tender.
Blend mixture until smooth.
Add chicken broth and cook over low heat until sauce thickens.
Dip corn tortillas in the sauce and fill with cooked chicken.
Roll and place in a baking dish.
Pour remaining sauce over enchiladas and top with crumbled queso fresco.
Bake at 375°F for 15 minutes.
Serve with a dollop of sour cream.
Poach chicken breast in water with onion and garlic until cooked through.
Shred chicken and set aside.
Saute diced onion and garlic in a little oil until tender.
Add shredded chicken, chipotle peppers, and canned tomatoes.
Simmer until mixture thickens.
Spread refried beans on tostadas and top with chicken mixture.
Add shredded lettuce, a dollop of sour cream, and crumbled queso fresco on top.
Dice tomatoes, onion, and jalapeno peppers.
Chop cilantro.
Mix all ingredients together in a bowl.
Season with lime juice and salt to taste.
Toast dried chiles in a dry skillet until fragrant.
Soak chiles in hot water until softened.
Blend chiles, canned tomatoes, onion, garlic, and chicken broth until smooth.
Cook mixture in a saucepan over low heat until thickened.
Roast poblano peppers over an open flame until the skins are charred.
Let the peppers cool and remove the skins.
Saute diced onion and garlic in a little oil until tender.
Add ground beef and cook until browned.
Add cumin, cooked rice, and crumbled queso fresco to the beef mixture.
Stuff the beef mixture inside the poblano peppers.
Beat egg whites until stiff peaks form.
Dip stuffed peppers in flour and then in the beaten egg whites.
Fry in hot oil until golden brown.
Cut pork shoulder into chunks.
Mix orange juice, lime juice, garlic, cumin, coriander, and salt together in a bowl.
Pour mixture over pork chunks and let marinate for at least an hour.
Heat oil in a Dutch oven or deep skillet.
Add pork chunks and cook until browned on all sides.
Cover and simmer until pork is tender and falls apart easily.
Remove from heat and let cool.
Shred pork and use in tacos or burritos.
Rinse rice in a fine mesh strainer until water runs clear.
Heat oil in a saucepan and add rice.
Cook rice until it is lightly browned.
Add diced onion and garlic and cook until onion is tender.
Add canned tomatoes, chicken broth, cumin, and salt.
Bring mixture to a boil, then reduce heat to low and cover.
Simmer for 20-25 minutes or until rice is cooked through and liquid is absorbed.

ingredients: 1 can black beans, drained and rinsed
cooking_method: In a large skillet over medium heat, cook the ground beef until browned and no longer pink. Add the taco seasoning and cook for another 5 minutes.
In a large bowl, combine the cooked beef, black beans, corn, and romaine lettuce.
Toss to combine and serve immediately.

ingredients: 1 lb boneless, skinless chicken breasts, cooked and shredded
1 can black beans, drained and rinsed
cooking_method: Preheat oven to 350°F.
In a large bowl, combine the shredded chicken, black beans, corn, and salsa.
Spoon a portion of the chicken mixture onto each tortilla and roll up.
Place the enchiladas in a baking dish and cover with foil.
Bake for 20-25 minutes, until heated through.
Remove from oven and serve immediately.

ingredients: 1 lb medium shrimp, peeled and deveined
cooking_method: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Add the shrimp and cook until pink, about 2-3 minutes.
Drain the shrimp and transfer them to a large bowl.
Add the lime juice, orange juice, red onion, jalapeño pepper, and salt to taste.
Toss to combine and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes, or until ready to serve.
Preheat the oven to 350°F.
Char the poblano peppers over an open flame or under the broiler until the skin is blackened.
Place the peppers in a paper bag and let them steam for 10 minutes.
Remove the skin, seeds, and membranes from the peppers and set them aside.
In a large skillet over medium heat, cook the ground beef until browned and no longer pink.
Add the onion and garlic and cook until softened.
Stir in the cilantro and season with salt and pepper to taste.
Stuff each pepper with the beef mixture and place them in a baking dish.
Bake for 15-20 minutes, until heated through.
Remove from oven and serve immediately.
Rinse the rice in a fine mesh strainer and drain well.
Heat the olive oil in a medium saucepan over medium heat.
Add the onion and garlic and cook until softened.
Stir in the rice and cook until lightly toasted.
Add the chicken broth and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for 18-20 minutes, until the rice is tender and the liquid is absorbed.
Fluff the rice with a fork and serve immediately.
Brown the ground beef in a skillet over medium heat.
Add taco seasoning and stir until meat is fully coated.
Remove from heat and let cool.
Chop lettuce and tomatoes.
Layer lettuce, meat, tomatoes, and cheddar cheese in a bowl.
Rinse the rice in a fine mesh strainer until the water runs clear.
Heat the oil in a large skillet over medium heat.
Add the rice and cook until lightly toasted, stirring frequently.
Add the onion and cook until softened.
Add the tomato sauce and chicken broth and stir to combine.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low and cover.
Cook for 18-20 minutes or until the liquid has been absorbed and the rice is tender.
Fluff with a fork before serving.
Toast the dried chiles in a dry skillet until they are fragrant, then soak them in hot water until soft.
Fry the onion, garlic, and tomatoes in oil until they are softened, then add the sesame seeds, almonds, and raisins and fry until the almonds are golden brown.
Grind the soaked chiles and spices in a blender until smooth, then add the fried mixture and blend again.
Heat the mole in a pot, adding chicken stock and chocolate until the mole is smooth and the chocolate is melted.
Serve with rice and chicken.
Marinate the pork shoulder in a mixture of achiote paste, guajillo chiles, pineapple, onion, garlic, oregano, cumin, coriander, and salt.
Roast the pork in the oven until it's cooked through, then slice it thinly.
Heat the tortillas on a griddle or in the oven.
Assemble the tacos by placing slices of pork on the tortillas and topping them with cilantro and lime juice.
Roast the poblano peppers until the skin is charred, then remove the skin and seeds.
Fry the ground beef with onion, garlic, tomatoes, raisins, almonds, olives, cinnamon, cumin, coriander, oregano, salt, and pepper.
Stuff the peppers with the beef mixture.
Beat the eggs until they're frothy, then add a little flour and beat again.
Dip the stuffed peppers in the egg mixture, then fry them in oil until they're golden brown.
Roast the poblanos under the broiler or on a gas stovetop until the skin is charred.
Place the peppers in a plastic bag and let them steam for 15-20 minutes.
Peel the skin off the peppers and make a small slit in each one to remove the seeds.
Stuff each pepper with queso fresco.
Roll the peppers in flour.
Beat the eggs until frothy.
Heat the oil in a large skillet over medium heat.
Dip the peppers in the egg mixture, coating them completely.
Fry the peppers in the hot oil, turning them once, until they are golden brown.
Drain on paper towels and serve hot.
Chop the tomatoes, onion, and jalapeno.
Combine the chopped vegetables with the cooked shrimp in a large bowl.
Squeeze lime juice over the mixture.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Chill in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes before serving.
Cook the chicken in a large pot of boiling salted water until cooked through, about 20 minutes.
Remove the chicken from the water and shred with two forks.
In a large skillet, sauté the onion and garlic until translucent.
Add the chipotle peppers and tomatoes to the skillet and cook until the tomatoes start to break down.
Add the shredded chicken to the skillet and stir to combine with the sauce.
Serve the chicken tinga on warm tortillas with your favorite toppings.
Grill or boil the corn on the cob until it is cooked through.
Brush the corn with mayonnaise.
Sprinkle cotija cheese over the corn.
Squeeze lime juice over the corn.
Sprinkle chili powder over the corn.
Serve hot.
Preheat the oven to 375°F.
Brown the ground beef in a large skillet.
Add the enchilada sauce to the skillet and stir to combine with the beef.
In a 9x13 inch baking dish, spread a thin layer of the beef mixture on the bottom.
Layer the corn tortillas over the beef mixture, cutting them to fit as necessary.
Spread a layer of black beans over the tortillas.
Repeat the layers until all ingredients are used, ending with a layer of tortillas on top.
Sprinkle shredded cheese over the top of the casserole.
Cover with foil and bake for 30 minutes.
Remove the foil and bake for an additional 10 minutes, or until the cheese is melted and bubbly.
Preheat oven to 375°F.
In a small bowl, mix together garlic powder, smoked paprika, chili powder, cumin, salt, and black pepper.
Place chicken breasts on a baking sheet and rub with olive oil. Sprinkle spice mixture over chicken, making sure to coat both sides.
Bake for 20-25 minutes or until chicken is cooked through.
Meanwhile, heat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add onion, red bell pepper, and green chilies. Cook for 3-4 minutes or until vegetables are tender.
Add chopped chipotle peppers to skillet and stir to combine.
Shred cooked chicken with two forks and add to skillet. Stir to combine.
To assemble tacos, warm corn tortillas in the microwave or on a griddle. Spoon chicken mixture onto each tortilla and top with shredded lettuce, crumbled queso fresco, and chopped cilantro.
Serve with sour cream and lime wedges.
In a small bowl, mix together sugar and cinnamon. Set aside.
In a shallow dish, whisk together eggs, milk, and vanilla extract.
Melt butter in a large skillet over medium-high heat.
Dip each slice of bread into egg mixture, making sure to coat both sides.
Place bread slices in skillet and cook for 2-3 minutes per side or until golden brown.
Remove bread from skillet and immediately sprinkle both sides with cinnamon sugar mixture.
Serve warm.
Cook the chicken in a large pot of boiling salted water until cooked through, about 20 minutes.
Remove the chicken from the water and shred with two forks.
In a large skillet, sauté the onion and garlic until translucent.
Add the chipotle peppers and tomatoes to the skillet and cook until the tomatoes start to break down.
Add the shredded chicken to the skillet and stir to combine with the sauce.
Serve the chicken tinga on warm tortillas with your favorite toppings.

Brush the corn with mayonnaise.
Sprinkle cotija cheese over the corn.
Squeeze lime juice over the corn.
Sprinkle chili powder over the corn.
Serve hot.
